text:
Thanks <@UMVFWPZ36>!

> long term advantages
Long term advantage would be code that is closer to specification, shorter and more maintainable. Also, easier to write, lowering the knowledge barier needed to build a web app and allowing faster prototyping.

> you really need a number of DSLS
I am not sure what exactly you mean by this, so pls correct me if I did not answer the question.
Idea of Wasp is that you get a lot of stuff done in a single DSL, that spans the concept of the whole web app. However, if there is something you need to customize in more details, and there is a good way out there to do it that people love, it probably makes more sense to do it that way then to reinvent the wheel in Wasp. Example of that is describing styling -> css is made for that and although it has its issues, people use it, and it would be too big task for us to reinvent it, so Wasp will not try to replace css, but instead allow using it. Same goes for html/jsx for layouting, React/Vue for reusable components, Javascript/TS for general / business logic.
Wasp as DSL serves the purpose of gluing this all together, removing unneeded complexity and hiding ugly/boring parts.

> language tooling
Good question! Since we are imagining it as a pretty horizontal DSL, I believe it will be very important to have a good way to discover options, so some kind of auto completion could help a lot. With LSP I am imagining this should not be so hard to develop for a couple of main editors, but I have never been developing language tooling so it is all a guess :).

I hope these answers are addressing the questions well - I would love to hear your opinions on these topics!

text:
I have been working on/with a new interaction model for livecoding for a while, and just put together the first comprehensive summary of the approach:
<https://s-ol.nu/alivecoding>
Feedback (both to text + content) very welcome!
cool! I think it would be nice to open the references in a new tab, on click. For me middle-clicking doesn't work (in chrome middle click opens tabs in a new window in the default event handler)
y u no capitalize

text:
<@UCUSW7WVD> good question... i intentionally don't capitalize headlines for stylistic reasons, but for the main text I honestly didn't notice I wasn't doing it until I finished, at which point I left it like that for today :sweat_smile:

Do you find it harder or distracting to read text like this?

text: <@UE0H4170F> that is up to the editor, the tool/language just adds tags and writes the file back to disk. I haven't done so yet (this is pretty early days, especially re editor supporg), but I do want to set up my editor to lose tags when copying, but keep them when cutting (deleting) content.

elements.text: that is up to the editor, the tool/language just adds tags and writes the file back to disk. I haven't done so yet (this is pretty early days, especially re editor supporg), but I do want to set up my editor to lose tags when copying, but keep them when cutting (deleting) content.

text: When I started thinking about this I thought that this tagging idea was going to break down at the latest when it gets to function calls or loops, but it turns out it actually works perfectly (tracking changes to function invocation and in the body of the definition, as well as closures etc) without losing any local state when reevaluating changes

elements.text: When I started thinking about this I thought that this tagging idea was going to break down at the latest when it gets to function calls or loops, but it turns out it actually works perfectly (tracking changes to function invocation and in the body of the definition, as well as closures etc) without losing any local state when reevaluating changes

text:
My lesson learned over many years is this: the things we are all proposing here are hard enough in their substance to even explain to others, let alone persuade them. We really have no leeway to be unique snowflakes about minor details of presentation. You really need to preserve your readers' cognitive resources for the core argument you're making.

Put another way: if I see something weird in your doc, it better be super critical to your doc. Otherwise I'm definitely gonna bounce.

The name of the game is becoming hard to dismiss.

text:
Ok, I just took another look at the article on the big screen and it makes a lot more sense to me now. Sorry, I'm a little sleep deprived so my comment above is harsher than usual.

I understand now that the critical thing to look at in the video is the grey numbers in square brackets. How are you managing that integration? What editor + tools is it using? And what is the moon tool on the right side? Is that part of what you built or some existing system?

text: <@UCUSW7WVD> fair enough. I didn't write this for the audience of this slack initially, it was meant more as a landing page for the project and posting it here was more of an afterthought. If I do publish this or a similar text "seriously" I will do that for sure :)

text: The `benefits` section isn't clear to me. Is it a pro and con list between two alternatives? Is the `dataflow` your approach, and the `textual representation and user-controlled evaluation moment` referring to previous approaches that simulate live-coding with an internal scratch buffer? If so, using the same words in different sections would help make these connections in my mind.

benefits

text: Is there a repo somewhere where I can just edit the text directly? Lots of little things here are driving me up the wall. And yet there's a core idea that is _extremely_ tantalizing and keeping me from bouncing. I want to make sure I'm understanding it clearly.

text:
<@UCUSW7WVD> the tool on the right is all of what I built. On the left there is a text editor (kakoune) - it is entirely stock except for syntax highlighting that tones down the tags a bit visually.

The tool on the right is evaluating (and modifying) the file whenever it is saved. You can find a more in-depth demo of an earlier version in this video: <https://youtu.be/ZXqgFb1U7q0|https://youtu.be/ZXqgFb1U7q0>

The code is public (<https://git.s-ol.nu/alivecoding|https://git.s-ol.nu/alivecoding>) but heavily wip. At this stage I'm trying to get feedback on the concept and some of the presentation, the project itself is not at the right status for proper sharing and distribution IMO.
